content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the contribution because it's fun and there are no issues any more

I had to read several times the challenge goal to understand what it is about but the challenge is fun and requires interesting skills.

It does not make sense why the unlabeled animals are decided by majority vote. I think some other story would make more sense but I guess it is more a question of taste.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: all issues seem to be fixed

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun challenge, love the animaux

The statement should explicitly mention the distance used.

There are sometimes more than "3 closest neighbors" in your testcases. For instance, in validator 4, for the 4th input the closest distances^2 are [20, 25, 49, 49, 50, ...] (the "3 closest" are actually 4) and for the 5th input they are [1, 2, 10, 10, 10, 17, ...] (the "3 closest" are 5). Said otherwise, in your solution code, the line "nn[distance(animal, (x,y))] = d[animal]" sometimes overwrites a previous value.

Also edited to fix the stub.

I think the statement could be a little bit clearer. How do I use the three nearest neighbors? Do I simply return the majority type of the three neighbors? I like the idea and the skillset needed, but the statement could be more clear about how you develop the output from the inputs. I also thought it took a few reads to understand what the inputs were, and they did not mirror the names found in the generator input.  You can read integers x, y, a instead of string row to make it more clear.
Thanks for your input! I will try and improve the statement. And indeed the generator input could be more specific.
Agreed, validator 4 has no correct outcome since the 3rd neighbour for 4th input can either be a cat or a dog. If both are considered the vote is equal.
Thanks for the feedback. I've adjusted the statement and solution code so that whenever there are more than 3  nearest neighbors you should pick whichever one is given first in the input.

Nope, what you did is keeping only the *first point* for the three smallest *distinct distances*, but this unfortunately doesn't make much sense...
For instance, in the 9th case of validator 2, the sorted distances^2 are [401, 401, 466, 820, 2041] and you choose to throw away the second 401 to compute the majority on the 3 points at distances [401 (first one), 466, 820], so clearly not the 3 nearest neighbors anymore!..
Ahh, I get it now. I'm gonna take a look at my code

No, still EXACTLY the same problems as those mentioned in my first message...
x_x

hey micheldore, what about you make it easy for the coders and yourself and just make sure there are only unique distance values in one set of inputs (also explicitly state this in the description).

Or you could state that if there are more than three neighbours because there are more than one 3rd neighbour, more than two 2nd neighbours, or more than three 1st neighbours, all of them count, in which case there has to be an unambiguous outcome (currently not the case).
Ok, conflicting inputs have been removed.
Ok true, missed one. Fixed it now
